item.title: Fresh anti-government protests in Iran as Trump threatens attack | DW News
item.author: DW News
item.content:encoded:
Fresh anti-government protests have broken out in Iran. Students beginning a new university term in the capital Tehran have rallied to remember the thousands killed in recent demonstrations. Meanwhile, the US is building up its naval task force in the region. President Trump has threatened another attack on Iran if the regime refuses to agree to a deal cutting its nuclear program.
00:00 Fresh protests in Iran 02:33 Ross Harrison, Middle East Institute
For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

item.author: euronews
item.content:encoded:
Iranian students renew anti-government protests in Tehran amid a US military buildup

item.title: BREAKING: US Secret Service kills armed man trying to enter Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago | DW News
item.author: DW News
item.content:encoded:
Breaking news: The US Secret Service says its agents shot and killed an armed man who tried to enter Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida. Trump was not there, and is currently in Washington, DC.
Authorities say the man was shot at the north gate of Mar-a-Lago. The suspect was from North Carolina, and in his early twenties. Investigators say he was reported missing by his family a few days ago.

item.title: ‘I can’t stay silent’: BAFTA-nominated film The Voice of Hind Rajab in focus
item.author: Ciaran Jenkins
item.content:encoded: One of the most talked-about films nominated at tonight’s BAFTAs is The Voice of Hind Rajab, based on the final phone call of a five-year-old girl in Gaza. We spoke to the filmmaker – and to Hind’s mother – about bringing her voice to the world.

item.title: Russia suspected over blasts appearing to target Ukrainian police
item.author: Harry Fawcett
item.content:encoded: Russia is thought to have been responsible for two bomb explosions which appear to have been set off to target Ukrainian police officers.A 23-year-old police woman was killed and several people were injured by two improvised explosive devices in Lviv.Russia also launched almost 300 drones and 50 missiles at Ukraine overnight.

item.title: How Fast is Japan’s Corporate Culture Changing?
item.author: Bloomberg Television
item.content:encoded:
For decades, Japan’s corporate identity was seen by many to be characterized by lifetime employment, keiretsu networks, and cautious capital allocation. Now, inflation, market reform, and investor pressure are forcing change. Leaders at Sony, Panasonic Automotive, and the Tokyo Stock Exchange are rethinking the way they do business.. But as Mireya Solís and Apollo’s Eiji Ueda explain, transforming balance sheets may be easier than transforming culture. -------- More on Bloomberg Television and Markets

item.title: Trump's new tariffs: What are Europe's options? | DW News
item.author: DW News
item.content:encoded:
Countries dependent on trade with the US are scrambling to figure out how Donald Trump's new tariff regime will affect them. The US president announced on Saturday he was raising a new levy on imports from 10 to 15 percent. Trump introduced that after the US Supreme Court ruled most of his previous trade tariffs were imposed illegally. Germany's Chancellor Friedrich Merz has warned that constant uncertainty about tariffs were "the biggest poison for the economies of Europe and the US." Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has urged Trump to treat all countries equally, saying Brazil did not want a new Cold War.
00:00 Countries respond to Trump's new tariffs 00:41 DW speaks with Claudia Schmucker, head of the Center for Geopolitics, Geoeconomics, and Technology at the German Council on Foreign relations 04:07 DW speaks with Alberto Rizzi, policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations
For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

item.title: Sony, Panasonic, and the Private Capital Boom Reshaping Japan
item.author: Bloomberg Television
item.content:encoded:
After decades of economic conservatism and cash hoarding, Japanese corporations are putting reform into practice. Spin-offs are accelerating, capital structures are shifting, and private capital is stepping in to finance transformation. From Panasonic Automotive’s carve-out under Apollo to Sony’s pivot from electronics to entertainment, Japan’s corporate leaders are embracing a new model for long-term competitiveness. -------- More on Bloomberg Television and Markets

item.title: Berlinale award winner criticizes Germany over its Gaza stance | DW News
item.author: DW News
item.content:encoded:
The 76th Berlin Film Festival - known as the Berlinale - has wrapped up for another year. But it ended on an overtly political note after one of the winners criticized the German government for its stance on Gaza. Abdallah Al-Khatib's film 'Chronicles from the Siege' won Best First Feature Film. During his acceptance speech, the Palestinian-Syrian director called for a free Palestine. DW's Matthew Moore reports from the studio in Berlin.

item.title: Trump doubles down on tariffs: How will the global economy react? | DW News
item.author: DW News
item.content:encoded:
Donald Trump is doubling down on his global trade tariffs. The president says he's raising a new levy on imports from the US's worldwide trading partners from 10 to 15 percent. Trump was responding to a United States Supreme Court ruling striking down most of his previous trade tarifffs. Justices ruled they were imposed illegally.
00:00 Trump doubles down on Tariffs 00:21 DW's Rosie Birchard reports from Brussels 04:37 DW speaks with Stephen Woolcock, Visiting Associate in the International Trade Policy Hub at the London School of Economics

item.title: Senegal in turmoil after student protest over financial aid | DW News
item.author: DW News
item.content:encoded:
Senegal is grappling with unrest after a wave of protest by students over unpaid financial aid. The situation worsened last week after a student died during the chaos in the capital Dakar. Prosecutors say Abdoulaye Ba fell from a dormitory as police clashed with students, but classmates insist officers beat him to death. The government has admitted there was "police misconduct." And anger is growing among the youth, as our correspondent Sira Thierij reports from Dakar.
00:00 Students in Senegal feal betrayed by government 04:27 DW speaks with Chris Ogunmodede, analyst and consultant in Dakar, Senegal
For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

item.title: Berlin film festival showcases Nigeria's 'Lady' | DW News
item.author: DW News
item.content:encoded:
This week, cinema's spotlight turn here to Berlin as the city hosts its annual film festival. Several African films are in the Berlinale lineup – some making their world premieres; others like the Nigerian feature ‘Lady’ being screened for the first time in Europe. 'Lady' is a feature-film debut for director Olive Nwosu. It follows a female taxi driver with big dreams as she navigates the bustling city of Lagos, until a reunion with a childhood friend drives her ideas of freedom in an unexpected direction. Filmmaker Olive Nwosu and actress Amana Oruh join DW in the studio.

item.title: Berlinale: Political drama 'Yellow Letters' wins Golden Bear award | DW News
item.author: DW News
item.content:encoded:
The 76th Berlin Film Festival has come to an end. Twenty films competed for the Golden and Silver Bears - and the winners were announced on Saturday evening. This year's event was overshadowed by discussions about its lack of a clear stance on Israel's alleged war crimes in Gaza. Despite the controversy, has the Berlinale managed to maintain its reputation as the most overtly political of the major European film festivals?

item.title: Will Trump be forced to refund $175 billion in revenue earned via his emergency tariffs? | DW News
item.author: DW News
item.content:encoded:
US President Donald Trump wants to impose a 10% global tariff on US trading partners after the Supreme Court ruled that his tariffs levied via the International Emergency Economic Powers ACT (IEEPA) are illegal, given that they bypassed approval from US Congress. US President Trump said the 6-3 ruling left him “deeply disappointed” and accused the Supreme Court of being "swayed by foreign interests”. President Trump vowed to deploy new methods to impose tariffs, including a sweeping new duty on all foreign trading partners.
Chapter Breakdown 0:00 SCOTUS opposes Trump's tariff regime 2:06 Jeffrey Frankel, Professor of Capital Formation and Growth, Harvard Kennedy School, on Trump's new 15% tariffs 6:37 Maurice Obstfeld, Senior Fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, on Trump's statutory authority to impose 15% tariffs
#ustariffs #trumptariffs #scotus

item.title: Over 3,000 people march in France in honour of far-right activist
item.author: euronews
item.content:encoded:
Over 3,000 people march in France in honour of far-right activist
On Saturday, Macron called for calm ahead of a demonstration in tribute to Quentin Deranque, whose murder has sent shockwaves through the country.
